perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS, Licensor is the owner of all rights to the trademark “Morgan Stanley” and the “Morgan Stanley” design (collectively, the “Brand”);
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS, Licensor is the owner of some rights to the trademark “Morgan Stanley” and the “Morgan Stanley” design (collectively, the “Brand”);
perturbation.explanation: Changing “all rights” to “some rights” regarding the Brand creates ambiguity about the extent of the licensor's ownership. Trademark law requires clear ownership for licensing. The modified text introduces uncertainty and could render the license unenforceable or give rise to disputes over the scope of rights granted, conflicting with established trademark law principles about ownership and control.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law, Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. § 1051 et seq.)

perturbation.original_text: Section 4.2. Termination for Convenience. Licensor reserves the right to terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice for any reason, including if the usage of the Brand is not in compliance with the standards and policies.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 4.2. Termination for Convenience. Licensor reserves the right to terminate this Agreement upon verbal notice for any reason, including if the usage of the Brand is not in compliance with the standards and policies.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "written notice" to "verbal notice" contradicts standard contract law requirements for providing clear and documented termination notice. Contract law typically requires termination notices to be in writing to provide a clear record and avoid disputes. This change creates uncertainty about how termination is to be communicated and proven, potentially leading to legal challenges.

perturbation.original_text: Section 9.4. Governing Law. THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE GOVERNED BY, AND CONSTRUED AND INTERPRETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH, THE LAW OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK. EACH OF THE PARTIES IRREVOCABLY AND UNCONDITIONALLY SUBMITS TO THE EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION OF THE STATE AND FEDERAL COURTS LOCATED IN NEW YORK CITY FOR THE PURPOSE OF ANY ACTION RELATING TO OR ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 9.4. Governing Law. THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE GOVERNED BY, AND CONSTRUED AND INTERPRETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH, THE LAW OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK. EACH OF THE PARTIES IRREVOCABLY AND UNCONDITIONALLY SUBMITS TO THE NON-EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION OF THE STATE AND FEDERAL COURTS LOCATED IN NEW YORK CITY FOR THE PURPOSE OF ANY ACTION RELATING TO OR ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: Changing “exclusive jurisdiction” to “non-exclusive jurisdiction” alters the legal venue for resolving disputes. 'Exclusive jurisdiction' means only New York courts can hear disputes, while 'non-exclusive' means other courts could also be appropriate. This creates uncertainty in where legal proceedings may occur, potentially conflicting with established jurisdictional clauses and increasing litigation costs if the parties disagree on the appropriate venue.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, Contract Law
